topics.title: Conviction as the signal to persist or quit
topics.summary: Scott explains his heuristic for founders in trouble: compare your current conviction (now that you know more) to your initial conviction. If conviction has increased, you’re likely in the “messy middle”; if it’s decreased, it’s time to quit or pivot.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Scott’s background (Behance founder, Adobe exec, author, investor) and previews topics: product sense, building fewer features, consumer products, and AI’s impact.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Braintrust (talent network), Eppo (A/B testing), and later Rows (modern spreadsheet with integrations and sharing).

topics.title: Scott’s new Adobe role and responsibilities
topics.summary: Scott describes moving from CPO to overseeing strategy, corporate development, company-wide design, and emerging products, driven by shifts like AI and new growth areas (3D/immersive, stock). He also outlines what his day-to-day looks like across these domains.

topics.title: Why Scott thrived as Adobe’s CPO
topics.summary: Scott attributes longevity to breaking down artificial boundaries between product, design, and engineering, emphasizing that user experience—not just technology—drives product success. He notes many CPO roles lack design/engineering scope, limiting impact.

topics.title: Building product sense through empathy and psychology
topics.summary: Scott argues product sense starts with deep customer empathy rather than attachment to a solution, and that great product work is applied psychology. He introduces the “first mile” concept: in the first 30 seconds users are lazy, vain, and selfish, so onboarding/orientation/defaults must minimize friction.

topics.title: First mile remains critical as customers evolve
topics.summary: Scott explains why onboarding must be continually redesigned: new cohorts are less forgiving and have different expectations. He uses Photoshop’s shift to subscription and a broader audience to illustrate how funnel changes force onboarding changes.

topics.title: How to build empathy: shoulder-to-shoulder research
topics.summary: Scott recommends observing customers in context—watching their whole day, not just product usage—to understand interruptions, constraints, and real workflows. This context builds intuition and enables teams to “be the customer.”

topics.title: Designing for surprise to drive word-of-mouth
topics.summary: Scott notes people don’t talk about products that meet expectations; they talk about unexpected delight (e.g., Tesla Easter eggs). He connects this to “magic tricks” in consumer products as a lever for organic growth.

topics.title: Why most new consumer apps fade quickly
topics.summary: Scott contrasts durable consumer winners (Uber, Pinterest) that created new network effects and unique psychological insights with “clever interface” apps that get copied by platforms. He argues many startups become de facto R&D for incumbents with distribution.

topics.title: What consumer success requires today (vs. 10 years ago)
topics.summary: Scott suggests users now tolerate more complexity and cognitive load (tabs, hidden menus), enabling platforms to absorb novel features rather than spawning standalone apps. He frames this as a shift from atomized apps toward more consolidated experiences.

topics.title: Build half the features: optimize for desired problems
topics.summary: Scott advises teams to ship only what gets users to value, and defer “nice-to-have” requests until users care enough to ask. He shares Behance lessons: removing underused features increased focus on the core metric, and most removals trigger brief outrage then silence.

topics.title: AI’s impact: from workflow to flow
topics.summary: Scott predicts AI will reduce mundane work and unlock human ingenuity, potentially increasing what companies attempt rather than shrinking teams. He argues AI mines the “center” (useful) while humans still find new edges, and expects more focus on experiences and non-scalable customer value.

topics.title: Collapsing the stack: cross-functional empowerment via AI
topics.summary: Scott expects fewer organizational handoffs as people self-serve insights and execution (e.g., less dependency on analysts for routine questions). He likens this to the advantage of small teams and suggests specialists can shift from repetitive requests to higher-leverage work.

topics.title: How AI changes PM work: explore more possibilities
topics.summary: Scott argues top performers win by exploring many options, narrowing, and iterating—something AI accelerates by expanding the surface area of ideas. He shares a filmmaker using ChatGPT for scenario exploration (not final scripts) as an analogy for product discovery.

topics.title: Design upstream, generative tools, and the “golden gut”
topics.summary: Scott describes pushing design earlier into product development and how generative AI will augment designers with rapid options and leaps (e.g., outpainting in Photoshop). He defines “golden gut” as experienced intuition for reducing cognitive load and making high-leverage micro-decisions in flows.

topics.title: Staying ahead with AI: play, write, and prioritize time
topics.summary: Scott’s advice is to actively experiment with AI tools to avoid getting stuck in old habits. He plugs his Implications newsletter as a forcing function for learning, discusses writing as a way to crystallize thinking, and shares the discipline required to carve out time.

topics.title: Surviving the messy middle: progress narratives and micro-goals
topics.summary: Scott explains why the middle is volatile and psychologically hard, and how teams must manufacture motivation through shared micro-milestones. He emphasizes “merchandising progress” so teams feel momentum despite uncertainty and anonymity.

topics.title: When to quit: conviction check for founders
topics.summary: Scott reiterates his decision rule: if you now have more conviction, persist; if you’d never start the company knowing what you know now, quit and pivot. He frames this as respecting life’s shortness and avoiding entrepreneurship without belief.
